content: two markers are your neck markers the 10 double_crochet space will sit at the nape of your neck fold your piece in half with your two markers touching find the center point between your markers not on the neck space but on what will become the top of your hood place a marker there this marker marks the top of your hood row 24-29 fasten on at your first neck marker you will be crocheting the long way around ​ ​ to your second neck marker chain 3 increase double_crochet in first two sts double_crochet across to center marker increase double_crochet in ​ center marker double_crochet across to end of row increase double_crochet in last two sts of the row 27dc 32dc 37dc 42dc 47 double_crochet finishing notes projection of the hood personally i like to take the last row of the hood and fold it over to give the brim of the hood a little extra stiffness so it holds its shape well you may decide to omit row 29 if you feel its too much fabric in the front length of the front points additionally you may want the front points of the hood to dangle lower in that case attach to a bottom front corner of the hood and working perpendicular to your previous row and work 9 double_crochet 2 half_double_crochet 2 single_crochet to the bottom of the hood this adds a triangle of extra fabric in the corner you can add multiple row this way until it is the desired length in the front repeat with the other corner adding tassels/braids/closures i added long braids to the front of my hood as an easy closure you can make long chains add scrappy pieces of fabric or go wild maybe you prefer a big chunky button or other closure steam blocking i steam blocked the hood to get it to lay a bit nicer both on the back of the head and along its length i steam blocked the hood itself vertically and the pointed end horizontally steam blocking helps to get all those different yarns to lay more nicely
